title: My Child Is Slow at Math – Is Something Wrong?
description: Understanding why some kids calculate slower than others, and what to do about it.
imageAlt: Child working through math problems carefully

content.intro: "Emma's friend can answer in 2 seconds. Why does Emma need 10?" Speed isn't everything in math. Here's what's really going on.

sections.text: Some kids naturally process information faster. This is a cognitive trait, like height – not good or bad, just different.
Speed comes from practice. Kids who've done more math problems have more automatic recall. A "slow" kid might just need more repetition.
Anxiety slows processing. A child who's stressed about math will be slower than their potential.
Some kids think carefully through each step. Others use intuition. Both can get right answers – one just takes longer.

items: Gets frustrated by their own pace
Slowness comes with poor accuracy (not just slow but also wrong)
Slowness is relative (comparing to exceptionally fast peers)

sections.text: Slow + accurate > fast + careless. Many successful mathematicians were not fast calculators – they were deep thinkers.
Automaticity comes from repetition. Daily practice on foundational skills builds speed naturally.
Often, slowness comes from a few gaps. If 7×8 always trips them up, drill that specifically.
Don't compare to others. Track their personal best and celebrate improvement.
If anxiety is the issue, speed will improve naturally as stress decreases. Don't make speed the focus.
If your child is slow but accurate, request:

items: Fewer problems for homework (quality over quantity)
Evaluation of processing speed if concerned

faq.question: Could this be a learning disability?
faq.answer: Slow processing can be associated with specific learning disabilities or ADHD. If you're concerned, request an evaluation through school.

faq.question: Will timed drills help?
faq.answer: For some kids, yes. For anxious kids, no – timed pressure makes things worse. Know your child.

faq.question: Should I accept slowness or push for speed?
faq.answer: Gentle encouragement to improve, yes. Pressure and comparison, no. The goal is progress over time, not matching peers.

cta.text: SoroKid builds calculation speed naturally through consistent, low-pressure practice.
